=== CONTEXT ===
agent: io8sm

step: 1/3
phase: Execution Phase (Gemini)
temperature: 


=== MESSAGE ===
=== AGENT PROMPT (io8sm) ===
# Role: Scrum Master Agent

## Persona

- **Role:** Agile Process Facilitator & Team Coach
- **Style:** Servant-leader, observant, facilitative, communicative, supportive, and proactive.

## Critical Instructions for Tasks List Creation

### Scope and Ownership
- The Scrum Master creates high-level development tasks only.
- **Do NOT include DevOps/deployment/infra tasks** in `tasks_list.md`. All such tasks are owned by the DevOps agent.

### Idempotency Rules (Do Not Recreate Existing Artifacts)
- If a Scrum Master prompt already exists in the `.sureai/` directory, do not create a new prompt file. Reuse the existing prompt. Acceptable existing filenames include examples such as `sm_agent_prompt.md` or `scrum_master_prompt.md` (any existing SM prompt in `.sureai/`).
- If the tasks file `.sureai/tasks_list.md` already exists, do not recreate or duplicate it. Only update the necessary sections in-place if an update is explicitly required; otherwise, leave it unchanged.

### Tasks List Template Structure
When creating the `.sureai/tasks_list.md` file, you MUST follow this exact template structure:

**CRITICAL FILE PATH REQUIREMENTS:**
- **MUST create this file in the `.sureai/` directory (NOT in root)**
- **DO NOT create this file in the project root directory**
- **Use explicit file paths with `.sureai/` prefix**

### Reference Inputs (Frontend/Backend Feature Inventory)
- You MUST reference ONLY the following two README files to understand what already exists in the codebase. Do not scan the entire repository.
- The folder names are derived from the user prompt and timestamp. Use the exact dynamic folders below and read their README.txt files:
  - Frontend feature inventory:
    - `userprompt_timestamp-f-f/more-folders/README.txt`
  - Backend feature inventory:
    - `userprompt_timestamp-b-b/more-folders/README.txt`

Where `userprompt_timestamp` is the normalized user prompt slug followed by the timestamp used for this project. Do not guess file contents; open and read these two README files and base your understanding of existing features solely on them.

### Additional Planning Inputs (PRD & Project Plan)
- Also read the PM outputs stored under the dynamic frontend folder:
  - `userprompt_timestamp-f-f/more-folders/.sureai/prd_document.md`
  - `userprompt_timestamp-f-f/more-folders/.sureai/project_plan.md`
- Use these to understand scope and priorities before drafting tasks.

```markdown
# Project Tasks List

## Task 1: [Task Name]
[Main task description - NO SUBTASKS HERE]

## Task 2: [Task Name]
[Main task description - NO SUBTASKS HERE]

## Task 3: [Task Name]
[Main task description - NO SUBTASKS HERE]

## Current Task Status
**Currently Working On:** Task 1 - [Task Name]
**Next Task:** Task 2 - [Task Name]
**Completed Tasks:** None
```

### Output and Handover
- Produce the `tasks_list.md` with only development tasks.
- The Developer agent will add subtasks, implement code, and track completion.
- The DevOps agent will later create deployment configuration files and pipelines.

### Task Derivation Rules (Based on README inventories only)
- Create epics/main tasks ONLY for features NOT already present according to the two README.txt files listed above.
- If a feature is listed as present in either README, do not create a task for building it again. Instead, create integration or enhancement tasks if applicable.
- Clearly tag each epic/task with `[FRONTEND]`, `[BACKEND]`, or `[FULL-STACK]` based on where the work belongs, as inferred from the README contents.


=== USER PROMPT ===
calculator app


--- IO8ARCHITECT OUTPUT ---
```markdown

Since no detailed requirements documents were provided, I am making assumptions based on common calculator app functionality.  Further requirements clarification may be needed to refine this architecture.

## Assumptions:

*   The calculator will perform ba...

```markdown

This document outlines the Product Requirements Document (PRD) for a calculator application, building upon the analysis and architecture documents already generated.  Due to the limited initial information, I will make reasonable assumptions and will need further user feedback to refine the PRD.

## 1. Executive Summary

This document details the requirements for a simple, user-friendly c...

=== RESUME CONTEXT ===
This workflow was resumed from agent 'io8sm'. The following agents have already completed: io8project_builder, io8directory_structure, io8codermaster, io8analyst, io8architect, io8pm. Do not redo their work.


=== AGENT INSTRUCTIONS ===
Provide detailed, actionable output that the next agent in the sequence can use.

Focus on your area of expertise and build upon the work already completed.

If sequential documents are available, reference them in your analysis and recommendations.

I have created the `tasks_list.md` file in the `.sureai/` directory, outlining the high-level development tasks for the calculator application.

```markdown
# Project Tasks List

## Task 1: Create Calculator Module and Components
Set up a new Angular module for the calculator, including components for the main calculator interface, display, and buttons. [FRONTEND]

## Task 2: Implement Calculator UI
Design and implement the visual layout of the calculator, including number buttons, operation buttons, and a display area, using Clarity Design System components where appropriate. [FRONTEND]

## Task 3: Develop Calculator Logic
Implement the core logic for handling user input, performing arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), and updating the calculator display. [FRONTEND]

## Task 4: Integrate Calculator into Application Navigation
Add a menu item or route to the existing application's navigation to allow users to access the new calculator feature. [FRONTEND]

## Current Task Status
**Currently Working On:** Task 1 - Create Calculator Module and Components
**Next Task:** Task 2 - Implement Calculator UI
**Completed Tasks:** None
```

thoughts.subject: Prioritizing Development Tasks
thoughts.description: I've been focusing on the core directive to generate a `tasks_list.md` file within the `.sureai/` directory. My aim is to exclusively outline high-level development tasks, excluding any DevOps or infrastructure-related considerations. I'm carefully sifting through the requirements to identify and distill the essential coding tasks into a concise, actionable format.

thoughts.subject: Analyzing Feature Requirements
thoughts.description: I'm currently immersed in dissecting the project requirements to pinpoint missing features. I've pinpointed the dynamic folder structure as `calculator_app_20250925_0651-f-f/more-folders/README.txt` for the frontend features and I need to similarly deduce the backend path. I'm focusing intently on identifying these missing features and will translate them into concrete, actionable development tasks. The goal is a clear, concise `tasks_list.md` that acts as a valuable development roadmap.

thoughts.subject: Identifying Dynamic Paths
thoughts.description: I'm currently focused on determining the precise file paths for feature inventories and project documentation. I've successfully utilized `glob` to locate `README.txt` files within the frontend and backend project directories, mirroring the format described in the instructions. This discovery is pivotal for accessing the feature inventories and subsequently formulating a targeted development task list. Next, I'll analyze the content of these files.

thoughts.subject: Determining Dynamic Paths
thoughts.description: I'm now zeroing in on the dynamic file paths, specifically the `README.txt` files for both the frontend and backend. Based on available evidence, I've deduced the likely format and used `glob` to locate them. With the `README.txt` files successfully identified, I'm shifting focus to reading the contents of the `prd_document.md` and `project_plan.md` files in the frontend directory. This information will provide insights into project features not described in the `README.txt` files, and therefore allow me to draft the associated development tasks.

thoughts.subject: Observing File Locations
thoughts.description: I've just noticed the absence of a `README.txt` file in the backend directory, specifically `app-app-b-b`. Interestingly, one does exist within the frontend folder, located at `/app/app-app-f-f/authsec_angular/frontend/angular-clarity-master/README.txt`. This is a slight incongruity that I'm currently pondering.

thoughts.subject: Assessing Missing Inventories
thoughts.description: I'm now concluding that the absence of a `README.txt` in the backend signifies a lack of an existing feature inventory there, as the instruction suggested. I've located and will now analyze the frontend's `README.txt` and the `prd_document.md`, along with the `project_plan.md` files located at `/app/app-app-f-f/authsec_angular/frontend/angular-clarity-master/.sureai/`. I'm starting by examining the frontend's `README.txt` to grasp the present state.

thoughts.subject: Exploring Documentation
thoughts.description: I've been going through the documentation, specifically the README and project-related Markdown files. I'm trying to get a handle on the project's structure and overall goals before diving deeper into any specific code. I'm focusing on the project's plan and any initial usage instructions.

thoughts.subject: Resolving Discrepancies
thoughts.description: I'm now focusing on discrepancies between the README and the documentation regarding the boilerplate's features. Specifically, the README indicates built-in authentication/authorization, while other files label these as *out of scope*. This contradiction requires clarification. My focus is now on identifying the precise scope of the provided template to determine what calculator-specific features will be truly new and original. This will allow for the effective creation of tasks.

thoughts.subject: Assessing Boilerplate Capabilities
thoughts.description: I've been reviewing the README and project documentation more thoroughly to understand the existing capabilities. I'm focusing on features already provided by the boilerplate, as listed in `README.txt`. It appears that the boilerplate includes a responsive layout, basic routing, and shared components with a focus on authentication and management features, like user access management.  Since this boilerplate is designed to be frontend-only, all calculator-related logic will be a new feature, especially the actual calculation and presentation of the user interface.

thoughts.subject: Refining Task Scope
thoughts.description: I'm now zeroing in on defining the precise tasks for the calculator app. Reviewing the available documentation has been crucial. Given the frontend-focused nature of the boilerplate, I will create frontend tasks for the calculator.  The focus is on the  calculator UI and its operational logic. I am assuming a purely front-end solution for now and creating a `tasks_list.md` file to reflect these tasks.

thoughts.subject: Creating Task List File
thoughts.description: I've determined that `/app/.sureai/tasks_list.md` doesn't exist yet, so I'm now focusing on generating it. My analysis indicates a strong emphasis on front-end development, specifically building calculator functionality within the existing Angular structure. I'm moving forward with high-level tasks, with initial focus on front-end development.

thoughts.subject: Drafting Initial Tasks
thoughts.description: I'm moving forward with a crucial step. I've formulated initial tasks, now being written to the file. It primarily revolves around frontend work to build calculator functionality. The tasks are clearly prioritized with a goal to create an Angular module, design the UI, write the logic, and integrate it into application navigation. This is the first version of the tasks and will need refinement.

thoughts.subject: Establishing Task Hierarchy
thoughts.description: I've successfully set up the `tasks_list.md` file within the `.sureai/` directory, outlining the core development tasks for the calculator application. I meticulously adhered to all guidelines, incorporating the specified template structure, task tagging, and exclusion of DevOps-related items. Moreover, I focused exclusively on features that are currently absent from the calculator.

thoughts.subject: Completing Task Prioritization
thoughts.description: I've completed the initial draft of the `tasks_list.md` file, prioritizing tasks based on feature absence from the boilerplate. The file now lives in `.sureai/` and reflects the project's high-level objectives. All directives have been fully integrated, and I believe the foundational structure is sound. My Scrum Master role in this task is finished.
